other_tests.findings: Bone union between fibular grafts and hosts was found 2 months postoperatively. The reconstructed distal ulna and contralateral limbs were growing almost simultaneously.
other_tests.changes_over_time: The morphology and function were satisfactory at 1- and 8-year follow-up. The radial articular angle improved from 40 degrees to 18 degrees, carpal slip decreased from 50 percent to 10 percent, and ulnar shortening improved from 14 mm to 5 mm, with a noted tendency toward premature epiphyseal closure 8 years postoperatively.

other_tests.findings: Radiography confirmed the presence of multiple hereditary osteochondromas, with preoperative findings including a radial articular angle of 35 degrees, carpal slip of 55 percent, and ulnar shortening of 22 mm.
other_tests.changes_over_time: Postoperative observations included correction of ulnar shortening within 2 weeks and bone union noted by 2 months. At 1-year follow-up, the radial articular angle was recorded at 30 degrees and carpal slip at 50 percent, with no recurrence of ulnar shortening.
